title: SideQuest
subtitle: Turning impulse into adventure
summary: A web app that gamifies spontaneity by helping young adults discover and complete random local activities through a quest-based interface.

overview.title: Overview
overview.description:
Ever had one of those Sundays where you're staring at your phone, scrolling for ideas, and nothing sounds good? You want to do something. You just don't know what.

SideQuest was designed for that exact moment. It's not a directory. It's not a list of recommendations. It's a randomized push to try something unexpected—framed like a video game quest to make it feel playful instead of overwhelming.

problem.title: The Problem
problem.description:
Traditional activity apps (Yelp, Google Maps, etc.) assume you know what you're looking for. But what about when you don't? What about when the goal isn't optimization—it's inspiration?

Young adults (especially those new to a city) face decision fatigue. Too many options. Too much browsing. No sense of urgency or fun.

research.title: Research & Framing
research.description:
We surveyed 30+ young adults about how they find and decide on activities. The data showed that most people spend more time browsing than doing. They wanted novelty, but searching felt like work.

Key insight: What if instead of presenting 100 options, we just gave them one? A random quest. Accept it or skip it. No browsing. No comparisons. Just commitment or rejection.

challenges.title: Early Challenges & Pivots
challenges.description: We tested several interaction models before landing on the quest-based approach.

pivots.to: Single randomized quest at a time
pivots.reason: Users got paralyzed by choice. A single option created urgency and playfulness.

pivots.from: Serious UI with location pins and ratings
pivots.to: Game-inspired UI with XP, levels, and rewards
pivots.reason: The serious UI felt like Yelp. Gamification made participation feel voluntary and fun.

pivots.to: Random generation based on time, location, and budget
pivots.reason: Users wanted variety. Handpicked lists felt stale after a few uses.

lofi.title: Lo‑Fi Wireframes
lofi.description:
The lo-fi phase was all about testing the core loop: tap to generate a quest, see activity details, accept or skip, repeat.

We sketched various card layouts, tested different information hierarchies, and explored how much detail to show upfront vs. after acceptance. The goal was frictionless exploration with minimal cognitive load.

iterations.title: High-Fidelity Designs
iterations.description:
The final visuals leaned into gaming aesthetics: bold colors, rounded shapes, progress bars, and reward animations. The interface was designed to feel responsive and alive—every tap had weight and feedback.

We iterated on micro-interactions (card flips, XP fills, level-up animations) to reinforce the sense of progression. Visual delight wasn't decoration—it was motivation.
improvements: Added XP bars and level progression to create long-term engagement
Introduced 'skip' and 'accept' swipe gestures for mobile-first interactions
Refined card layouts to prioritize activity type, time commitment, and proximity
Added emoji-based visual tags for quick activity scanning
Emphasized micro-animations for quest acceptance and completion

solution.title: Final Solution
solution.description: SideQuest generates one random activity at a time based on your location, available time, and budget. Accept it and it becomes your active quest. Complete it and earn XP. Skip it and get a new one. No browsing. No overthinking.

features.title: Randomized Quest Generation
features.description: Activities are randomly assigned based on contextual filters. Users don't choose—they react. This removes decision fatigue.

features.title: XP & Progression System
features.description: Completing quests earns XP. Leveling up unlocks badges and stats. Gamification creates habit loops.

features.title: Time & Budget Filters
features.description: Quick settings let users adjust how much time and money they're willing to commit without leaving the quest screen.

features.title: Skip or Accept Interactions
features.description: Simple binary choice. No infinite scrolling. Users commit or move on.

validation.title: Validation & User Testing
validation.description: Beta testers consistently mentioned two things: it felt low-pressure, and it got them out the door. One user said they accepted a quest to visit a farmers market they'd walked past for months but never entered. Another mentioned that the timer added just enough urgency to override their usual indecision.

quotes.text: I liked that I couldn't overthink it. I just hit accept and went.
quotes.author: Beta tester

quotes.text: The XP system made me want to keep going. I didn't expect that.
quotes.author: Beta tester

insights.title: Randomness creates commitment
insights.description: When users don't have to choose, they feel less responsible—and more willing to try something new.

insights.title: Gamification drives behavior change
insights.description: XP and levels weren't just decorative. They created small dopamine loops that encouraged repeat usage.

insights.title: Constraint is clarity
insights.description: Limiting to one quest at a time reduced cognitive load and increased action.

nextSteps.title: Next Steps
items: Add social features—friends can challenge each other to complete specific quests
Expand quest categories beyond activities (e.g., food challenges, cultural experiences)
Build backend logic for smarter randomization based on user history and preferences
Test group quest mode for shared adventures
